section.title: Building Hexagonal Ice from Crystal Information
section.para: Similar in spirit to the alumina example, here we create a single ice Ih crystal from the crystal information, and then replicate it to form a larger supercell. The crystal information used below is from Leadbetter et al., J. Chem. Phys., vol 82, p424-428 (1985), Table II (Structural parameters of ice at 5 K).

sect5.title: 1. Create the Unit Cell
sect5.para: First, we create the unit cell, which from the paper is orthorhombic with side lengths A = 4.5019, B = 7.7978, and C = 7.328 Å. The view may need adjusting in order to see the whole cell.

row.entry: Add a unit cell to the model by checking the 'Has Cell?' checkbox.
Set the cell lengths A, B, and C to 4.5019, 7.7978, and 7.328 respectively.

sect5.title: 2. Add the Unique Atoms
sect5.para: There a five symmetry-unique atoms to add into the cell. This might seem odd given that this doesn't add up to a whole number of water molecules, but one of the water molecules lays with its oxygen on a mirror plane, and so only needs one hydrogen to be specified. Atom positions in the paper are given in fractional coordinates - we will create the atoms using these coordinates which will be converted by Aten into their real (cell) coordinates automatically.

row.entry: On the Build toolbar change the active element to oxygen by clicking the button and selecing it in the periodic table.

sect5.title: 3. Set the Spacegroup and Pack
sect5.para: To complete the model the spacegroup of the crystal must be set, so that generation of the symmetry-related atoms can be performed. On the cell page, enter the spacegroup as either 'Cmc21' or '36', then select Pack to generate the symmetry-related atoms from the current cell contents using the specified spacegroup's generator definitions. In the image shown below, the atoms have also been folded into the unit cell (Ctrl-F).

row.entry: Open the Cell Edit window again
Enter the spacegroup as "Cmc21" or "36" and press 'Set' to assign the spacegroup to the model
Generate symmetry equivalent atoms by pressing the 'Pack' button

sect5.title: 4. Replicate Cell and Calculate Bonds
sect5.para: The basic cell of ice Ih isn't particularly interesting, so we will replicate the cell to create a larger supercell of the ice crystal, and then calculate bonds in the new model so that the hexagonal structure is clear to see.
